title: Running
text: For as long as I can remember, I have been involved in all kinds of sports. Despite not having much success in soccer and baseball, they set a strong competitive baseline in me. In my sophomore year of high school, I joined the track team where my perfect attendance at practices and consistent work led to improvement and two captain roles. I really cherished my short three years with the team, but I left discouragement after a frustrating senior year of injuries and underwhelming results.

title: Running
text: For as long as I can remember, I have been involved in all kinds of sports. Despite not having much success in soccer and baseball, they set a strong competitive baseline in me. title: Running
text:
Consistency
During my time in community college, I never got into a routine of running. Once I moved into my apartment after transferring schools, I had the North Campus Open Space and the Elwood Mesa as my backyard. Having the rare combination of clean air, endless dirt trails, and year-round greenery made running much more enjoyable than the concrete sidewalks of my suburban hometown. Running is something I look forward to and I try to fit about three runs a week into my schedule.

title: Running
text:
Accessiblity
Social media discourse in 2025 about a running influencer collaborating with the White House Press Secretary brought massive attention to how interconnected running and politics are. An administration that guts clean air regulations, cuts programs that provide healthy food to kids, and targets transgender athletes, should not be welcomed by the running community. The conversation made me further realize how much of a privilege it is to run with access to adequate food and gear. It is a goal of mine to work towards making running more accessible through tangible actions, such as working with the Associated Students of UCSB’s Edible Campus Program and Department of Public Worms who both help fight food insecurity on campus by providing fresh produce to all students.

title: Projects
About
text:
Hi! My name is Kai Suzuki and I am a third-year Environmental Studies (B.S) student at the University of California, Santa Barbara. I have had my mind set on studying the environment, and more broadly conservation goals, since a young age. I spent two years at Orange Coast College, where I received my Associates of Science (A.S.) degree. My environment growing up is something I cherish and is a deep inspiration to my academic goals.
At UCSB, I have contributed to local restoration efforts at the Storke Ranch Open Space and the North Campus Open Space. At Storke Ranch, I had the chance to work with Lasthenia glabrata ssp. coulteri, an endangered native vernal pool plant.
I will also start a position as a Worm Wrangler at the Department of Public Worms in Summer 2025, where I am excited to help make the campus a more sustainable and food-sovereign place. Outside of school and work, you can find me drinking coffee, cooking, gardening, running, and watching baseball (Go Angels!).

title: Kai Suzuki
text:
About Me
I am an undergraduate studying Environmental Studies with a deep passion for conservation. I am always looking for opportunities in fieldwork and restoration projects, particularly in California coastal ecosystems. Feel free to contact me via LinkedIn or Email!


Education
Environmental Studies, B.S.
University of California, Santa Barbara (2024-2026)
Natural Sciences, A.S.
Orange Coast College (2022-2024)


Experience
Aquatic Invertebrate Lab Intern
Cheadle Center for Biodiversity & Ecological Restoration (Jan 2025-Present)
Restoration Intern
Storke Ranch Open Space (Jan-Mar 2025)
